Hosting, CMS & Domain Names

Performance Optimisation

Performance Optimisation

Step 1 - Test

Website Speed Test

First we recommend using a website speed test tool to analyze the overall speed of your website. There are lots of options, but KeyCDN is a good choice.

This will let you see how long it takes to load each asset (files, images, scripts, etc) as well as the order in which they load.

Another option is GTMatrix website performance test which will run a waterfall and speed test, as well as give a list of potential items to check off. One this to bear in mind with this though is that it can sometiems give suggestions that aren’t possible or important to your site in particular. For example, on the Institute of Code site they flag ‘leverage browser caching’ on our site with an F because many of the resources aren’t using caching – but you’ll notice most are also third party resources that we don’t have the ability to cache. So learn from the insights, but don’t freak out if you see a few bad grades and feel free to share the link on the facebook group if you want help deciphering anything.

Responsive Testing

Using Chrome inspect element on your site and then turn on device view to test the site at certain device sizes.

You shouldn’t rely on this as your own responsive test though, as some rendering will differ from this simulation to the actual phone… you should be testing your website on at least one iPhone and one android phone to for responsive bugs by clicking through each page one by one.

Browser Testing

Each browser takes your code and renders the html, css and javascript into a visual, interactive website. The way it interprets and renders the same code though can yield different results – your site can look and interact differently on different browsers. Start by testing your site on browsers you actually have installed, like Firefox and Chrome, and either Safari or Internet Explorer. Other tools like Browsera allow you to test multiple browsers at once and the free version is good for up to 25 pages, and Netrendererallows you to test sites on old versions of Internet Explorer.

Step 2 - Boosting your website performance

Write Clean, Efficient Code

Building your site from scratch using modern web standards (HTML5, CSS3 etc) is one of the best things that you can do to enhance the perforance of your site, and if you have taken this course you are likely already doing that.

You want to aim to create your site using the minimal amount of code possible, so take effort to delete unused code, to consolidate where you have written the same css properties multiple times, and remove resources (ie fonts, libraries, plugins) that you are no longer using.

For example, rather than adding the property text-align: center on dozens of elements and selectors, consider creating a class of center that you can use anywhere you want to center text.

There are some more advanced tools available like Helium that let you scan your site for unused css selectors, but their usage is beyond the scope of this course. You can also use Chrome Developer tools to indentify which css styles aren’t used on each page – if you used this on every page of your site you could figure out which css styles weren’t used at all.

Optimising your images / videos

Using a 5000pixel wide image is not only going to slow your site down it’s also likely to not add much value because few people are using a screen so big that they coudl see the full size, high resolution image. Edit the image size using the default app on your computer (Preview for Mac) down to a maximum of 1200 pixels wide for a full-width image.

You can resize a whole folder of images at the same time using Bulk Resize

Then to further boost speed, use an image compression service like TinyPng that will losslesslycompress the image making the file smaller with minimal impact on the quality of the image. It does this by consolidating similar colours (maybe instead of 50 variations of blue it brings it down to 10 variations) and a number of other sublte strategies.

For custom-built sites, optimising images is typically the most important thing you can do for your sites page load speed.

Use a CDN

Using a CDN, or content delivery network, is one of the easiest things you can do to speed up your site. CloudFlare is free and easy to set up, so you would be crazy not to use it! It also comes standard with CloudCannon if you are using that as your hosting.

Using Static HTML & CSS or a Static Site Generator like Jekyll

This is already the default for most of your students but the speed and performance improvements of using static site generators over dynamic sites using wordpress or Joomla are huge. You can read all about that here.
